STICKMEN BEAT MT. WASHINGTON
Varsity Forges Ahead toward End of
Game, Administering 4-2 Defeat to
Hillmen—Captain Baxley Continues Steady Shooting.

The Varsity lacrosse team
gained a well-earned victory on
Saturday, April 20, over the Mt.
Washington club by a score of
4 to 2. The game was fast and
clean from start to finish, both
sides showing flashes of brilliant
playing, and it was the sort of
contest which will popularize
the sport here.
The Hillmen aggregation was
composed of former stars from
Swarthmore, University of Penn,
sylvania, and Hopkins, and despite the lack of consistent team
play, their individual work was
of the highest order, forcing the
'Varsity to extend itself to the
limit. The Hopkins team, however, was greatly weakened by
the absence of Sutton and Silberstein who were prevented from
starting
' on account of injuries
sustained in the Navy, game.
Daugherty also was absent, but
Sadtler, who took his place at
goal, made a very creditable
showing.
Bauernschmidt, who started the
game at first attack, made the
first score after four minutes of
play. The visitors Were not long
in evening matters, Johnny
Knipp, netting the ball with the
tying goal, as a result of splendid
attack work on the part of Mt.
Washington. From then on to
the end of the half, it was a seesaw affair with honors about
even.
The second half produced an
even better brand of lacrosse,
and frequent shots at goal were
made by each side, but none entered the net. Finally, Gail shot
one past Sadtler, and it seemed
that there would be no more
scoring. At this point Silberstein was sent in for Bauerenschmidt, and the Hopkins attack
took a new lease on life. Baxley
got two goals in rapid succession, and Hoffman netted one just
before the whistle blew.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1919.

BLACK AND BLUE WARRIORS WALLOP
OPPONENTS WITH STICK AND BAT
Maryland State Stickmen Smothered by 17-0 Score. Captain
Littman and Elmer Jones Carry off Slugging Honors
in 13-4 Baseball Victory—Love Pitches
Steady Game.

Captain Littman.

Frank Morley.

"Litty" collected a homer, a double, and a single in Saturday's game. Morley has been a big contribUtor to this season's
splendid defense work.
Collecting fourteen hits for a
total of twenty bases off Powell's
delivery, Eddie Hooper's ball
tossers trounced the University
of North Carolina to the tune of
13-4. The cold, windy day did not
seem to suit the Southerners, who
made nine boots in the course of
the battle.
Hopkins took the lead with
one tally in 'the second round.
The Carolinians tied the count
in the next inning, but then the
local team hit its stride and
pulled away. One runner crossed
the plate in the third, four more
in the fourth; in the sixth another quartet of tallies was rung
up, and three more counters were
added to the total in the last two
rounds.
Littman and Elmer
Jones starred with the willow,
collecting all the extra-base hits
made by the home team, including three doubles and a home run.
Sharretts and Bloomsburg each
garnered two singles.
A lightning double play on the
part of Littman and Bloomsburg
gave the spectators .a thrill in
the sixth. With one down and
men on first and second, Feimester knocked a hot grounder to
Littmann who fielded it perfectly
(Continued on page 8, col. 2)

The 'Varsity lacross team gave
• Maryland State one of the worst
lacings ever seen at Homewood
field on last Saturday when it
defeated the farmers 17 to 0. As
the score indicates, the game was
decidedly one-sided, and State
was clearly outclassed. It was
originally arranged for Penn
state to play, but at the last
moment they were forced to
abandon their trip, and Maryland State was asked to act as
substitutes.
From the start, it was evident
that it would be merely a question of how large the score would
be, although for a while State
gamely prevented _ any score.
But after Blum shot the first
goal, eight others followed in
rapid, succession making the
score at the end of the first half
9 to 0. During the entire first
half the pall was in State territory and the 'Varsity attack had
little trouble out-playing their
opponents. Superior stick-work
and a better knowledge of the
finer points of the game gave
Hopkins a decided advantage in
team work, with which their opponents could not cope.
(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

RELAY TEAM BREAKS RECORD
Van Ness, Driver, Bartels, and Smith
Capture Championship of Southern
States, Smashing Previous S.
A. 1. A. A. Records.

At one of the largest track
meets ever held by the University
of Pennsylvania, the Hopkins relay team established a new record in the S. A. I. A. A. for the
mile relay. This is the third
time that the championship of
the southern states has come to
Baltimore, the team having taken
first place at the Penn Relay
Carnival in 1918, at the Second
Regiment Indoor Games at Baltimore in 1919, and again at Philadelphia on Saturday, April 26.
Although the absence of Firor
was a great loss to the team, J.
Bartels substituted in a very able
style. The team traveling up to
Philadelphia consisted of Captain
B. Smith, A. Taylor, W. Driver,
J. Bartels, and B. VanNess, together with Coach England. The
other entries in the S. A. I. A. A.
mile relay were Georgetown and
Catholic University.
Van Ness ran as first man for
Hopkins, and
although
the
Georgetown runner dropped his
baton, there was an appreciable
gain handed to Driver, the second of the Hopkins quartet.
Driver, running a great race,
more than held his own, and was
able to give a lead of some three
yards to Bartels, who added another yard by the end of his
quarter. Captain Smith, even
though greatly handicapped by a
strained tendon in his leg, had
things all his own way on the
last lap and crossed the finish
line ten yards ahead of Georgetown. The time of the team,
which broke the S. A. I. A. A.
record, was 4 minutes 32 1-5 seconds, which was 52-5 seconds better than the time of the previous
year.
The men returned in time for
the concert and dance at Homewood where the silk banner and
the individual gold watches, the
awards, were much admired by
everyone.
The result of the race was
watched with interest, for this
coming Saturday Hopkins meets
Georgetown in a dual track and
field meet at Washington:
A navy school of turbine engineering has been established at
the Carnegie Institute of Technology by the Naval Auxiliary Reserve. The purpose of the course
is to train naval officers in the
efficient operation of steam turbines as applied to ship drive.

Swarthmore and Navy Outpoint Black
and Blue—Capt. Smith and Leadbetter;iStar in Both Meets—
Absence of Firor Felt.

With the loss of Firor and the
lack of supporting men, the Hopkins track team met with two defeats during the Easter vacation.
The first meet was with Swarthmore, and although the Hopkins
men had the advantage of their
home track, they were the losers
by the score of 76 to 36 to a better balanced squad. The scoring
was practically the duplicate of
that of 1918, minus the points
which the absence of Firor forfeited.
B. Smith and Guy Leadbetter
were the two highest point winners for Hopkins, the former with
firsts in the 440-yard dash and
half-mile run, the latter pulling
10 points with a first in the shot
and in the discus, breaking the
Hopkins record in this event with
a throw of 125 feet 8/
1
2 inches.
The surprise of the meet was the
winning of first place in the high
hurdles by R. Wood, a freshman.
Wood has shown remarkable form
in clearing the jumps, and with a
little more experience can be
counted upon as a sure point winner.
Running, under the same difficulties, Hopkins suffered a severe
defeat at the Naval Academy on
Wednesday, April 23, by a score
of 96/3 to 2873. Although Captain Smith and Leadbetter won
their usual two first places apiece,
with three places counting, the
Navy men had no competition for
second or third places in many of
the events. There was excellent
time made in the mile and halfmile runs, considering the slow
track.
The Navy results follow: Smith
first in the 100 and 440 yard
dashes. Leadbetter- first in* the
shot and discus, and third in the
javelin. W. V. Evans tied for
second in the high jump. R. Wood
two thirds in the hurdles. Bartels third in the mile. The relay
team took second place.
The results of the Swarthmore
meet are as follows:

HIGH GRADE CHOCOLATES.

At a recent meeting of the men
interested in the Y. M. C. A., the
following officers for the new year
were elected: President, Charles
T. Leber; vice-president, T. T.
Burger; secretary H. H. Mersereau; treasurer, William Merriken. Mr. Leber is especially well
suited to take charge of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. through his long
experience in this kind of work.
Plans for the new year were
talked over at the meeting. It
was decided that the vocational
talks, as well as the addresses by
other prominent men, would be
continued either under the direct
supervision of the local Y. M.
C. A. or under thp partial direction of the University.
The social service department
is also to be extended in its educational work among the illiterate foreigners, and the vocational
training in the social settlement
houses and, play grounds. The
deputation work among the
churches of the nearby country
towns will be renewed under a
larger program.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1919

THE NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of Richard
L. Field and Edward T, Norris
from the Editorial Board.
Two Are Very Good-looking.

You have sat through problem
plays at Ford's, gazed with interest at the Auditorium's shimmying senoritas, and laughed at
the recurrent jokes and still more
recurrent stars at the Maryland.
But now something new for the
ennuied, sons of Hopkins looms
up upon the historic horizon.
Our own talent is to hold forth
at Albaugh's on May 7th, and
from all reports is to present a
performance that will place Hopkins on a dramatic par with
other universities which have
had years of experience and tradition in this line.
It is surprising that the University has been for so many
years without a dramatic club,
when practically all the large institutions and many like Haverford with small enrollments, have
for years sent delegates before
the footlights.
At last, however, a club of
which we may well be proud, has
been organized. The cast has for
months past given up afternoons,
evenings, and Saturday mornings
for rehearsals. They have done
their share in every way toward
putting Hopkins on the dramatic
An excellent play by
map.
George Bernard Shaw has been
selected; and a talented and, for
the most part, experienced cast

See how bravely and lovingly the embryo M. D.'s fondle their
predecessors. This doughty dozen should revolutionize the science
by discovering formulas for curing red noses or preventing headaches on the morning after. All luck to them!
has worked hard 'under the tutelage of an able coach. The
finishing touches have been
added; all that is now needed is
an audience.
The club looks to the student
body to support the play. It is
surely the Hopkins man's duty to
back this new activity, which is
everywhere recognized as most
beneficial to a university. Full
recognition should be accorded
the labors of those who have had
the initiative to organize a club
which, in its first year, can put
forth a production which draws
such unlimited praise from those
who have seen recent rehearsals.
There is not alone the incentive of Hopkins loyalty, but far
more that of pure enjoyment.
Just picture three of our heroes
portraying female roles—and sh
they . say two of them are extremely good-looking. Imagine,
if you can, words of wisdom and
epigrammatic sentences falling
from the lips of our "Barn"
orators. Dolly, Valentine, the
Waiter, Mrs. Glandon—all will
be historic characters. The play
will be the talk of the University.
You don't want to say you weren't
there.
Buy your tickets, call her up
if you haven't done so, and do all
you can to promote the success
of the baby activity. Try to give
the performers stage fright with
the size of the audience.
Senior Engineers on Trip.

Prof. J. H. Bringhurst, accompanied by five seniors, left on
Sunday evening, April 27, on a
civil engineering trip to Norfolk,
Va. The party is to make an inspection of the construction
methods of the new government
dry docks as described by Admiral Harris in his Aldred lecture on March 12.
Professor Bringhurst and his
men will spend Monday and
Tuesday in Norfolk and its vicinity, and will make as thorough
a study as possible of the steel
eonstruction in that neighborhood.

FOSSIL HUNTERS ENJOY TRIP
Devil's Race Course, High Rock Observatory at Pen Mar, Dan's Rock, and
Borden Coal Mine Among
Points of Interest.

Dr. Swartz's band of twentythree trilobite chasers boarded
the train last Monday morning
for the annual geological—to say
nothing of terpsichorean and
bachanalian—outing. The party,
whose appearance suggested a
congregation of boy scouts, carpenters and letter-carriers, alighted at Blue Ridge Summit, and,
after visiting time "Devil's Race
Course" and other points of interest, secured entertainment for
the night at Waynesboro, Pa.
The jazz artists, finding that the
inhabitants, through some oversight, had failed to provide a suitable reception, turned a peaceful
dancing class, augmented by the
younger set of Waynesboro, into
a regular jardin de danse.
At 6.15 next morning the
weary band arose for a climb to
High Rock near Pen Mar.
Walking at the usual slow pace
of the instructor—something between a dog-trot and a gallop—
the class reached the summit and
drunk in the beauties of the scenery. Only a few indomitable
spirits pressed on to Quirank,
where a magnificent view was to
be had.
Berkeley Springs, reputed to be
a representative town of West
Virginia, was the next victim of
the itinerant geologists. With
characteristic hospitality, the
West Virginia lads arranged a
subscription dance in honor of
the Hopkins delegation, many of
whom had to borrow funds from
then on. Staying at the ball as
long as possible, the dancers did
not retire till nearly ten.
The travelers next invaded the
quaint, simple little village of
Cumberland, where bars are often
a full half-block apart. There the
society element of the class received invitations to a luxurious-

/Emil
Tintips
--With that
something
that college
men like

ly appointed dance held in the
large hall just over the Cumberland livery stable. Forgetting
the next day's hike, the social
lions shook wicked Wymans and
slippery Schlesingers till the wee
hours. The fair sex of the town,
with their picturesque vernacular,
were reported by the invited to be
irresistible.
Next morning teams were procured from Frostburg. As there
was the usual delay in getting
the class together for the early
start, Dr. Swartz was about to
call the roll, when Herbert put
in an appearance and "Doc"
knew that all were there. An
amusing incident occurred at the
Devil's Backbone, when some adventurous spirits scaled the cliff,
dislodging a boulder which
crashed down into the crowd.
However, it missed some of the
elect, who were taking notes, by
more than a yard.
Returning to Cumberland the
roving geologists stayed rather
close to the hotel, preferring the
warmth of the rooms to the snow
outside. Next morning Dan's
Rock was climbed in the midst
of a light snow, and in the afternoon came the descent into the
Borden coal mine, one of the most
interesting experiences of the
trip. At 6:00 p. m. the party
boarded the train for Baltimore,
agreeing that the trip had been
most instructive and enjoyable.
Within a short time, $175,000
has been given by 100 Lehigh
alumni towards completing a fund
for a memorial building for Lehigh men killed in the service.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 29, 1919.

PHI BETA KAPPA MEN CHOSEN
Six Undergraduates Receive Keys—
Thirteen Graduate Students in Medicine and Philosophy also
Honored.

The annual meeting of the Alpha Chapter of Maryland of the
Phi Beta Kappa Society was held
in the Donovan ROOM on Tuesday, April 15. On the basis of
their scholarship during their residence at the University, the following collegiate students were
elected to membership in the society: Frank Thomas Fenneman,
Beverly Waugh Smith, Jr., Roszel Cathcart Thomsen, Leo William Simon Karl Wilhelm Ebeling, Lester'
Stern Levy* and Gregory Breit.
Most men in the Departments
of Literature and Economics realize what "sharks" Fenneman,
Thomsen, Smith and Simon are.
Ebeling is first among the "premeds," while Breit shines in physics. Thomsen, besides standing
so well in his studies is editor of
the Hullabaloo and a member of
the debating team. Simon is also
a debater and a Member of the
Dramatic Club, while "Bev"
Smith is captain of the track
team. Levy should have been
elected last year, but was omitted
from the list by mistake, as he
was graduated in February, in
order to enter the army.
The following .men were also
elected:
Graduate Students in Philosophy — Herbert Insley, William
Lawrence Wanlass and Robert
Parran Strickler.
Graduate Students in Medicine
—Charles Edwards Parsons, William Francis Reinhoff, Jr., Leslie
Tillotson Webster, Elizabeth Mintie Reese, Irwin Clement SchuCatherine Greighton,
macher
Anne Peril Purdy, Leonard Tomb
Davidson and Henry Morgan
Winans.

INVITED TO JOIN SOUTHERN
ORATORICAL LEAGUE

In a letter to Dr. John C.
French from Dr. Edward C.
Mabie of the University of Kentucky, Johns Hopkins has been
invited to enter a Southern Oratorical League. It is suggested
that the first contest of the league
will probably take place in 1920.
Pending the formation of a definite and permanent constitution a
tentative agreement has lieen submitted. It provides that the business of the League shall be conducted by an executive committee
composed of one member of the
faculty of each of the institutions
accepting this agreement.
Only persons who are pursuing
undergraduate studies at the time
of the contest and who have not
received academic degrees shall
be admitted as competitors.
Speeches must not exceed twenty
minutes in delivery, and must
deal with political, social, or economic subjects of current interest. Extempore speaking shall be
agreed to be preferable to speaking from memory. Prizes shall
be awarded at the discretion of
the executive committee.
Copies of this tentative agreement are being sent to the following universities beside Hopkins:
Vanderbilt University, University
of Tennessee, University of Alabama, University of Virginia,
University of North Carolina,
University of Kentucky.
Spring Football Practice Progresses.

Spring football practiCe on the
lower field is now well under way,
as far as other sports and activities will permit. At present it
is possible to hold only two field
work-outs each week, for a number of men who would otherwise
be out at these practices are engaged in some spring sport.
As soon as the spring sports
are over, the last game scheduled
is May 24th, the tryouts for the
fall training camp will be held.
During this period of three weeks
before the undergraduate examinations are held, the entire squad
will be expected out for light but
intensive work-outs daily.
The plan now on foot is to pick
from these men a certain number
who are showing up well and
working faithfully to go to an
early camp to be held during September. The advantages these
men will have over the others are
only too obvious, and it is not
impossible that the entire 'Varsity may be picked from their
number. The benefits which Hopkins will get are equally obvious.

MANY OFFICERS VISIT UNIT;
"R.0. T. C. EXCHANGE" STARTED.

Within the last few weeks the
R. 0. T. C. has begun preparations for the annual inspection,
has been visited by many officers
from other colleges, and has
started "The R. 0. T. C. Exchange."
The unit is being worked into
shape for the annual Government
inspection to be held on May 19
and 20. Col. J. B. Douglas, of
the General Staff, will be the reviewing officer. The whole R. 0.
T. C. will be called out for two
days previous to the inspection,
in order thoroughly to drill the
men, and it will remain out for
the entire two days of the inspection.
A number of officers have recently visited the University to
find out the details of the organization of the R. O. T. C. unit
here. In a visitors' book that was
recently begun appear the following names: Col. S. R. Bull, Lieut.Col. Alex M. Hall and Lieut.-Col.
R. Butler, from the Third District headquarters at Philadelphia; Second Lieut. Stanley S.
Wohl, commandant of the Grove
City College R. 0. T. C.;'and._
Major G. A. Matile, commandant
of the Maryland State College R.
0. T. C.
The new "R. 0. T. C. Exchange"
is a periodical published "with a
view to awakening interest in an
exchange periodical devoted to the
interests of the R. 0. T. C. of the
country." For the time being this
paper is published bi-monthly,
free of charge, by the George Banta Publishing Company. The first
number was largely devoted to the
Hopkins R. 0. T. C. Subsequent
issues are to be dedicated to the
R. 0. T. C.'s of other colleges.
There is to be a slight charge
for the paper later on, and it is
hoped that before long the paper
will be self-supporting. If each
of the 300 R. 0. T. C. units were
to subscribe to only 10 copies per
issue of the "Exchange," the paper could be made a self-supporting monthly.
Junior Class Banquet to be Held
May 19th.

At the last meeting of the Junion Class, held Tuesday, April 15,
the plans of the Banquet Committee were explained in detail by
George Wagner. The banquet
will be held May 19 at the Emerson. John H. Levin has been selected as toastmaster. Music will
be furnished by a string quartet.
Radcliffe and Harvard have
successfully cooperated in bringing out a new literary magazine.

GLEE CLUB CONCERT PLEASES
Haverford and Johns Hopkins Vie for
Musical Honors.

Large and appreciative was the
audience that attended the Hayerford-Johns Hopkins Musical
clubs concert, and many were the
expressions of appreciation given
the performers. The Haverford
Mandolin club included some accomplished players of the banjo,
xylophone, and traps, as well a
full set of mandolins and violins.
Their Glee club likewise gave a
most creditable exhibition of
their powers over the elusive note.
The Hopkins club gave only
four of the numbers, but it was
hard to realize that the organization had been in existence less
than three months. All of the
credit is due to Director Bochau,
who has worked untiringly with
the students. The best number
was the Haverford "Victory
March," by the mandolin club.
The "Anaesthetic" dancing was
both extremely original and
highly amusing.
The dancing that followed fully
came up to all expectations. The
chairs flew out of the hall in a
manner fearful and wonderful to
behold, the floor being ready be:
fore the orchestra was. After the
first few dances the crowd thinned out just enough to give the
rest a bit of leeway.

STICKMEN BEAT MT. WASHINGTON
Varsity Forges Ahead toward End of
Game, Administering 4-2 Defeat to
Hillmen—Captain Baxley Continues Steady Shooting.

The Varsity lacrosse team
gained a well-earned victory on
Saturday, April 20, over the Mt.
Washington club by a score of
4 to 2. The game was fast and
clean from start to finish, both
sides showing flashes of brilliant
playing, and it was the sort of
contest which will popularize
the sport here.
The Hillmen aggregation was
composed of former stars from
Swarthmore, University of Penn,
sylvania, and Hopkins, and despite the lack of consistent team
play, their individual work was
of the highest order, forcing the
'Varsity to extend itself to the
limit. The Hopkins team, however, was greatly weakened by
the absence of Sutton and Silberstein who were prevented from
starting
' on account of injuries
sustained in the Navy, game.
Daugherty also was absent, but
Sadtler, who took his place at
goal, made a very creditable
showing.
Bauernschmidt, who started the
game at first attack, made the
first score after four minutes of
play. The visitors Were not long
in evening matters, Johnny
Knipp, netting the ball with the
tying goal, as a result of splendid
attack work on the part of Mt.
Washington. From then on to
the end of the half, it was a seesaw affair with honors about
even.
The second half produced an
even better brand of lacrosse,
and frequent shots at goal were
made by each side, but none entered the net. Finally, Gail shot
one past Sadtler, and it seemed
that there would be no more
scoring. At this point Silberstein was sent in for Bauerenschmidt, and the Hopkins attack
took a new lease on life. Baxley
got two goals in rapid succession, and Hoffman netted one just
before the whistle blew.

BLACK AND BLUE WARRIORS WALLOP
OPPONENTS WITH STICK AND BAT
Maryland State Stickmen Smothered by 17-0 Score. Captain
Littman and Elmer Jones Carry off Slugging Honors
in 13-4 Baseball Victory—Love Pitches
Steady Game.

Captain Littman.

Frank Morley.

"Litty" collected a homer, a double, and a single in Saturday's game. Morley has been a big contribUtor to this season's
splendid defense work.
Collecting fourteen hits for a
total of twenty bases off Powell's
delivery, Eddie Hooper's ball
tossers trounced the University
of North Carolina to the tune of
13-4. The cold, windy day did not
seem to suit the Southerners, who
made nine boots in the course of
the battle.
Hopkins took the lead with
one tally in 'the second round.
The Carolinians tied the count
in the next inning, but then the
local team hit its stride and
pulled away. One runner crossed
the plate in the third, four more
in the fourth; in the sixth another quartet of tallies was rung
up, and three more counters were
added to the total in the last two
rounds.
Littman and Elmer
Jones starred with the willow,
collecting all the extra-base hits
made by the home team, including three doubles and a home run.
Sharretts and Bloomsburg each
garnered two singles.
A lightning double play on the
part of Littman and Bloomsburg
gave the spectators .a thrill in
the sixth. With one down and
men on first and second, Feimester knocked a hot grounder to
Littmann who fielded it perfectly
(Continued on page 8, col. 2)

The 'Varsity lacross team gave
• Maryland State one of the worst
lacings ever seen at Homewood
field on last Saturday when it
defeated the farmers 17 to 0. As
the score indicates, the game was
decidedly one-sided, and State
was clearly outclassed. It was
originally arranged for Penn
state to play, but at the last
moment they were forced to
abandon their trip, and Maryland State was asked to act as
substitutes.
From the start, it was evident
that it would be merely a question of how large the score would
be, although for a while State
gamely prevented _ any score.
But after Blum shot the first
goal, eight others followed in
rapid, succession making the
score at the end of the first half
9 to 0. During the entire first
half the pall was in State territory and the 'Varsity attack had
little trouble out-playing their
opponents. Superior stick-work
and a better knowledge of the
finer points of the game gave
Hopkins a decided advantage in
team work, with which their opponents could not cope.
(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

RELAY TEAM BREAKS RECORD
Van Ness, Driver, Bartels, and Smith
Capture Championship of Southern
States, Smashing Previous S.
A. 1. A. A. Records.

At one of the largest track
meets ever held by the University
of Pennsylvania, the Hopkins relay team established a new record in the S. A. I. A. A. for the
mile relay. This is the third
time that the championship of
the southern states has come to
Baltimore, the team having taken
first place at the Penn Relay
Carnival in 1918, at the Second
Regiment Indoor Games at Baltimore in 1919, and again at Philadelphia on Saturday, April 26.
Although the absence of Firor
was a great loss to the team, J.
Bartels substituted in a very able
style. The team traveling up to
Philadelphia consisted of Captain
B. Smith, A. Taylor, W. Driver,
J. Bartels, and B. VanNess, together with Coach England. The
other entries in the S. A. I. A. A.
mile relay were Georgetown and
Catholic University.
Van Ness ran as first man for
Hopkins, and
although
the
Georgetown runner dropped his
baton, there was an appreciable
gain handed to Driver, the second of the Hopkins quartet.
Driver, running a great race,
more than held his own, and was
able to give a lead of some three
yards to Bartels, who added another yard by the end of his
quarter. Captain Smith, even
though greatly handicapped by a
strained tendon in his leg, had
things all his own way on the
last lap and crossed the finish
line ten yards ahead of Georgetown. The time of the team,
which broke the S. A. I. A. A.
record, was 4 minutes 32 1-5 seconds, which was 52-5 seconds better than the time of the previous
year.
The men returned in time for
the concert and dance at Homewood where the silk banner and
the individual gold watches, the
awards, were much admired by
everyone.
The result of the race was
watched with interest, for this
coming Saturday Hopkins meets
Georgetown in a dual track and
field meet at Washington:

With the loss of Firor and the
lack of supporting men, the Hopkins track team met with two defeats during the Easter vacation.
The first meet was with Swarthmore, and although the Hopkins
men had the advantage of their
home track, they were the losers
by the score of 76 to 36 to a better balanced squad. The scoring

that of 1918, minus the points
which the absence of Firor forfeited.
B. Smith and Guy Leadbetter
were the two highest point winners for Hopkins, the former with
firsts in the 440-yard dash and
half-mile run, the latter pulling
10 points with a first in the shot
and in the discus, breaking the
Hopkins record in this event with
a throw of 125 feet 8/
1
2 inches.
The surprise of the meet was the
winning of first place in the high
hurdles by R. Wood, a freshman.
Wood has shown remarkable form
in clearing the jumps, and with a
little more experience can be
counted upon as a sure point winner.
Running, under the same difficulties, Hopkins suffered a severe
defeat at the Naval Academy on
Wednesday, April 23, by a score
of 96/3 to 2873. Although Captain Smith and Leadbetter won
their usual two first places apiece,
with three places counting, the
Navy men had no competition for
second or third places in many of
the events. There was excellent
time made in the mile and halfmile runs, considering the slow
track.
The Navy results follow: Smith
first in the 100 and 440 yard
dashes. Leadbetter- first in* the
shot and discus, and third in the
javelin. W. V. Evans tied for
second in the high jump. R. Wood
two thirds in the hurdles. Bartels third in the mile. The relay
team took second place.

HIGH GRADE CHOCOLATES.

At a recent meeting of the men
interested in the Y. M. C. A., the
following officers for the new year
were elected: President, Charles
T. Leber; vice-president, T. T.
Burger; secretary H. H. Mersereau; treasurer, William Merriken. Mr. Leber is especially well
suited to take charge of the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. through his long
experience in this kind of work.
Plans for the new year were
talked over at the meeting. It
was decided that the vocational
talks, as well as the addresses by
other prominent men, would be
continued either under the direct
supervision of the local Y. M.
C. A. or under thp partial direction of the University.
The social service department
is also to be extended in its educational work among the illiterate foreigners, and the vocational
training in the social settlement
houses and, play grounds. The
deputation work among the
churches of the nearby country
towns will be renewed under a
larger program.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1919

THE NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of Richard
L. Field and Edward T, Norris
from the Editorial Board.
Two Are Very Good-looking.

You have sat through problem
plays at Ford's, gazed with interest at the Auditorium's shimmying senoritas, and laughed at
the recurrent jokes and still more
recurrent stars at the Maryland.
But now something new for the
ennuied, sons of Hopkins looms
up upon the historic horizon.
Our own talent is to hold forth
at Albaugh's on May 7th, and
from all reports is to present a
performance that will place Hopkins on a dramatic par with
other universities which have
had years of experience and tradition in this line.
It is surprising that the University has been for so many
years without a dramatic club,
when practically all the large institutions and many like Haverford with small enrollments, have
for years sent delegates before
the footlights.
At last, however, a club of
which we may well be proud, has
been organized. The cast has for
months past given up afternoons,
evenings, and Saturday mornings
for rehearsals. They have done
their share in every way toward
putting Hopkins on the dramatic
An excellent play by
map.
George Bernard Shaw has been
selected; and a talented and, for
the most part, experienced cast

See how bravely and lovingly the embryo M. D.'s fondle their
predecessors. This doughty dozen should revolutionize the science
by discovering formulas for curing red noses or preventing headaches on the morning after. All luck to them!
has worked hard 'under the tutelage of an able coach. The
finishing touches have been
added; all that is now needed is
an audience.
The club looks to the student
body to support the play. It is
surely the Hopkins man's duty to
back this new activity, which is
everywhere recognized as most
beneficial to a university. Full
recognition should be accorded
the labors of those who have had
the initiative to organize a club
which, in its first year, can put
forth a production which draws
such unlimited praise from those
who have seen recent rehearsals.
There is not alone the incentive of Hopkins loyalty, but far
more that of pure enjoyment.
Just picture three of our heroes
portraying female roles—and sh
they . say two of them are extremely good-looking. Imagine,
if you can, words of wisdom and
epigrammatic sentences falling
from the lips of our "Barn"
orators. Dolly, Valentine, the
Waiter, Mrs. Glandon—all will
be historic characters. The play
will be the talk of the University.
You don't want to say you weren't
there.
Buy your tickets, call her up
if you haven't done so, and do all
you can to promote the success
of the baby activity. Try to give
the performers stage fright with
the size of the audience.
Senior Engineers on Trip.

Prof. J. H. Bringhurst, accompanied by five seniors, left on
Sunday evening, April 27, on a
civil engineering trip to Norfolk,
Va. The party is to make an inspection of the construction
methods of the new government
dry docks as described by Admiral Harris in his Aldred lecture on March 12.
Professor Bringhurst and his
men will spend Monday and
Tuesday in Norfolk and its vicinity, and will make as thorough
a study as possible of the steel
eonstruction in that neighborhood.

FOSSIL HUNTERS ENJOY TRIP
Devil's Race Course, High Rock Observatory at Pen Mar, Dan's Rock, and
Borden Coal Mine Among
Points of Interest.

Dr. Swartz's band of twentythree trilobite chasers boarded
the train last Monday morning
for the annual geological—to say
nothing of terpsichorean and
bachanalian—outing. The party,
whose appearance suggested a
congregation of boy scouts, carpenters and letter-carriers, alighted at Blue Ridge Summit, and,
after visiting time "Devil's Race
Course" and other points of interest, secured entertainment for
the night at Waynesboro, Pa.
The jazz artists, finding that the
inhabitants, through some oversight, had failed to provide a suitable reception, turned a peaceful
dancing class, augmented by the
younger set of Waynesboro, into
a regular jardin de danse.
At 6.15 next morning the
weary band arose for a climb to
High Rock near Pen Mar.
Walking at the usual slow pace
of the instructor—something between a dog-trot and a gallop—
the class reached the summit and
drunk in the beauties of the scenery. Only a few indomitable
spirits pressed on to Quirank,
where a magnificent view was to
be had.
Berkeley Springs, reputed to be
a representative town of West
Virginia, was the next victim of
the itinerant geologists. With
characteristic hospitality, the
West Virginia lads arranged a
subscription dance in honor of
the Hopkins delegation, many of
whom had to borrow funds from
then on. Staying at the ball as
long as possible, the dancers did
not retire till nearly ten.
The travelers next invaded the
quaint, simple little village of
Cumberland, where bars are often
a full half-block apart. There the
society element of the class received invitations to a luxurious-

/Emil
Tintips
--With that
something
that college
men like

Hub
Baltimore Street At Charles

ly appointed dance held in the
large hall just over the Cumberland livery stable. Forgetting
the next day's hike, the social
lions shook wicked Wymans and
slippery Schlesingers till the wee
hours. The fair sex of the town,
with their picturesque vernacular,
were reported by the invited to be
irresistible.
Next morning teams were procured from Frostburg. As there
was the usual delay in getting
the class together for the early
start, Dr. Swartz was about to
call the roll, when Herbert put
in an appearance and "Doc"
knew that all were there. An
amusing incident occurred at the
Devil's Backbone, when some adventurous spirits scaled the cliff,
dislodging a boulder which
crashed down into the crowd.
However, it missed some of the
elect, who were taking notes, by
more than a yard.
Returning to Cumberland the
roving geologists stayed rather
close to the hotel, preferring the
warmth of the rooms to the snow
outside. Next morning Dan's
Rock was climbed in the midst
of a light snow, and in the afternoon came the descent into the
Borden coal mine, one of the most
interesting experiences of the
trip. At 6:00 p. m. the party
boarded the train for Baltimore,
agreeing that the trip had been
most instructive and enjoyable.
Within a short time, $175,000
has been given by 100 Lehigh
alumni towards completing a fund
for a memorial building for Lehigh men killed in the service.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 29, 1919.

PHI BETA KAPPA MEN CHOSEN
Six Undergraduates Receive Keys—
Thirteen Graduate Students in Medicine and Philosophy also
Honored.

The annual meeting of the Alpha Chapter of Maryland of the
Phi Beta Kappa Society was held
in the Donovan ROOM on Tuesday, April 15. On the basis of
their scholarship during their residence at the University, the following collegiate students were
elected to membership in the society: Frank Thomas Fenneman,
Beverly Waugh Smith, Jr., Roszel Cathcart Thomsen, Leo William Simon Karl Wilhelm Ebeling, Lester'
Stern Levy* and Gregory Breit.
Most men in the Departments
of Literature and Economics realize what "sharks" Fenneman,
Thomsen, Smith and Simon are.
Ebeling is first among the "premeds," while Breit shines in physics. Thomsen, besides standing
so well in his studies is editor of
the Hullabaloo and a member of
the debating team. Simon is also
a debater and a Member of the
Dramatic Club, while "Bev"
Smith is captain of the track
team. Levy should have been
elected last year, but was omitted
from the list by mistake, as he
was graduated in February, in
order to enter the army.
The following .men were also
elected:
Graduate Students in Philosophy — Herbert Insley, William
Lawrence Wanlass and Robert
Parran Strickler.
Graduate Students in Medicine
—Charles Edwards Parsons, William Francis Reinhoff, Jr., Leslie
Tillotson Webster, Elizabeth Mintie Reese, Irwin Clement SchuCatherine Greighton,
macher
Anne Peril Purdy, Leonard Tomb
Davidson and Henry Morgan
Winans.
Member of the Academic Staff
—Edward Wilbur Berry.

INVITED TO JOIN SOUTHERN
ORATORICAL LEAGUE

In a letter to Dr. John C.
French from Dr. Edward C.
Mabie of the University of Kentucky, Johns Hopkins has been
invited to enter a Southern Oratorical League. It is suggested
that the first contest of the league
will probably take place in 1920.
Pending the formation of a definite and permanent constitution a
tentative agreement has lieen submitted. It provides that the business of the League shall be conducted by an executive committee
composed of one member of the
faculty of each of the institutions
accepting this agreement.
Only persons who are pursuing
undergraduate studies at the time
of the contest and who have not
received academic degrees shall
be admitted as competitors.
Speeches must not exceed twenty
minutes in delivery, and must
deal with political, social, or economic subjects of current interest. Extempore speaking shall be
agreed to be preferable to speaking from memory. Prizes shall
be awarded at the discretion of
the executive committee.
Copies of this tentative agreement are being sent to the following universities beside Hopkins:
Vanderbilt University, University
of Tennessee, University of Alabama, University of Virginia,
University of North Carolina,
University of Kentucky.
Spring Football Practice Progresses.

Spring football practiCe on the
lower field is now well under way,
as far as other sports and activities will permit. At present it
is possible to hold only two field
work-outs each week, for a number of men who would otherwise
be out at these practices are engaged in some spring sport.
As soon as the spring sports
are over, the last game scheduled
is May 24th, the tryouts for the
fall training camp will be held.
During this period of three weeks
before the undergraduate examinations are held, the entire squad
will be expected out for light but
intensive work-outs daily.
The plan now on foot is to pick
from these men a certain number
who are showing up well and
working faithfully to go to an
early camp to be held during September. The advantages these
men will have over the others are
only too obvious, and it is not
impossible that the entire 'Varsity may be picked from their
number. The benefits which Hopkins will get are equally obvious.

MANY OFFICERS VISIT UNIT;
"R.0. T. C. EXCHANGE" STARTED.

Within the last few weeks the
R. 0. T. C. has begun preparations for the annual inspection,
has been visited by many officers
from other colleges, and has
started "The R. 0. T. C. Exchange."
The unit is being worked into
shape for the annual Government
inspection to be held on May 19
and 20. Col. J. B. Douglas, of
the General Staff, will be the reviewing officer. The whole R. 0.
T. C. will be called out for two
days previous to the inspection,
in order thoroughly to drill the
men, and it will remain out for
the entire two days of the inspection.
A number of officers have recently visited the University to
find out the details of the organization of the R. O. T. C. unit
here. In a visitors' book that was
recently begun appear the following names: Col. S. R. Bull, Lieut.Col. Alex M. Hall and Lieut.-Col.
R. Butler, from the Third District headquarters at Philadelphia; Second Lieut. Stanley S.
Wohl, commandant of the Grove
City College R. 0. T. C.;'and._
Major G. A. Matile, commandant
of the Maryland State College R.
0. T. C.
The new "R. 0. T. C. Exchange"
is a periodical published "with a
view to awakening interest in an
exchange periodical devoted to the
interests of the R. 0. T. C. of the
country." For the time being this
paper is published bi-monthly,
free of charge, by the George Banta Publishing Company. The first
number was largely devoted to the
Hopkins R. 0. T. C. Subsequent
issues are to be dedicated to the
R. 0. T. C.'s of other colleges.
There is to be a slight charge
for the paper later on, and it is
hoped that before long the paper
will be self-supporting. If each
of the 300 R. 0. T. C. units were
to subscribe to only 10 copies per
issue of the "Exchange," the paper could be made a self-supporting monthly.
Junior Class Banquet to be Held
May 19th.

At the last meeting of the Junion Class, held Tuesday, April 15,
the plans of the Banquet Committee were explained in detail by
George Wagner. The banquet
will be held May 19 at the Emerson. John H. Levin has been selected as toastmaster. Music will
be furnished by a string quartet.
Radcliffe and Harvard have
successfully cooperated in bringing out a new literary magazine.

GLEE CLUB CONCERT PLEASES
Haverford and Johns Hopkins Vie for
Musical Honors.

Large and appreciative was the
audience that attended the Hayerford-Johns Hopkins Musical
clubs concert, and many were the
expressions of appreciation given
the performers. The Haverford
Mandolin club included some accomplished players of the banjo,
xylophone, and traps, as well a
full set of mandolins and violins.
Their Glee club likewise gave a
most creditable exhibition of
their powers over the elusive note.
The Hopkins club gave only
four of the numbers, but it was
hard to realize that the organization had been in existence less
than three months. All of the
credit is due to Director Bochau,
who has worked untiringly with
the students. The best number
was the Haverford "Victory
March," by the mandolin club.
The "Anaesthetic" dancing was
both extremely original and
highly amusing.
The dancing that followed fully
came up to all expectations. The
chairs flew out of the hall in a
manner fearful and wonderful to
behold, the floor being ready be:
fore the orchestra was. After the
first few dances the crowd thinned out just enough to give the
rest a bit of leeway.
